title.narrative: Core Support to Transparency International Georgia 2018-2021

description.narrative: The overall objective of the intervention is defined as "to support building and empowering state institutions, develop good governance and the rule of law, ensure the transparency and direct accountability of the state institutions, support fair and democratic elections (for this aim including election observations) and protect universally recognized human rights". For achieving overall objectives the intervention plans to achieve few specific objectives: Objective 1: Contribute to reduced opportunities for corruption (including high-level corruption) in the executive branch Objective 2: Contribute to greater transparency and accountability in local government Objective 3: Promote transparency, accountability, and integrity in Parliament and effectiveness of Parliament as an oversight institution Objective 4: Promote more pluralistic political system through greater transparency and accountability in political parties and more competitive and fair elections Objective 5: Promote independence, transparency, accountability, and integrity in the justice system Objective 6: Promoting independence, professionalism and investigative activities of journalists to empower media as an anti-corruption watchdog Objective 7: Counter anti-Western propaganda and promote unbiased information about Georgia’s European and Euro-Atlantic integration Outcome targets for those specific objectives are given in the result matrix. They are assessed as achievable, given that external risks associated with slow down of Georgia's overall reform process not will be materialised and the country will continue its reforms and its way on developing democratic, accountable and transparent governance.

Transparency International (TI) Georgia applied to the Embassy for funding in form of core support for the years 2018 - 2021 with a volume of 15 000 000 SEK.
TI Geogia works in the area of anti-corruption and good governance with the aim to increase transparency and accountability in national and local government in Georgia. TI works through advocacy, monitoring and capacity building in close cooperation with both state actors and civil society.
TI Georgia believes that its activities as a watch dog and think tank in areas of anti-corruption policy, judicial reform, parliamentary democracy, local government, elections, political and campaign finance, media, economic policy will lead to reducing opportunities for corruption through transparency, accountability and integrity in key institutions in Georgia that is ultimate goal of the intervention.
The overall objective of the intervention is defined as "to support building and empowering state institutions, develop good governance and the rule of law, ensure the transparency and direct accountability of the state institutions, support fair and democratic elections (for this aim including election observations) and protect universally recognized human rights". The intervention objective is assessed as relevant to the Swedish strategy and its support to Georgia.
This will be phase two of the core support provided to TI Georgia, the phase one of the support lasted 2015-2017 and it was assessed as successful and having contributed to Georgia´s democratic development.

Transparency International (TI) har ansökt om kärnstöd för perioden 2018-2021 med en total budget på 15 MSEK.
Genom att arbeta med antikorruption och god samhällsstyrning strävar TI efter att öka transparens och ansvarsutkrävande inom regeringen på både nationell och lokal nivå. TI arbetar med påverkansarbete, uppföljning och kapacitetsuppbyggnad i nära samarbete med såväl statliga aktörer som med civilsamhälleorganisationer.
TI anser att de aktiviteter som de genomför som tankesmedja och Watch-dog, genom att arbeta med transparens, ansvarsutkrävande och integritet inom nyckelinstitutionerna i Georgien, kommer att minska korruption inom viktiga områden som rättsväsendet, parlamentarisk demokrati, lokala myndigheter, valprocesser, politisk finansiering, media och ekonomisk politik.
Insatsens huvudsyfte är att ”bidra till uppbyggande och förstärkande av statliga institutioner, utveckla god samhällsstyrning och rättssäkerhet, upprätthålla transparens och ansvarsutkrävande inom statliga institutioner, stödja rättvisa och demokratiska valprocesser (inklusive valobservation) och "försvara internationellt erkända mänskliga rättigheter ”. Insatsens mål anses vara relevant för genomförande av Resultatstrategin.
Detta kommer att vara fas två av kärnstödet till TI Georgia. Fas 1 pågick under 2015-2017 och bedömdes vara både framgångsrik och anses ha bidragit till Georgiens demokratiska utveckling.

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.5 - Substantially reduce corruption and bribery in all their forms.
16.5 - Väsentligt minska alla former av korruption och mutor.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats Kärnstöd till TI Georgia 2018-2021

description.narrative: The annual report provided by TI Georgia gives a lot of examples of the activities by the organisation in 2020. Some activities will lead to even impact level results potentially. For example in June TI Georgia published National Integrity System Assessment (NIS). The previous NIS assessment was released in 2015 and had a significant impact on the public discourse over the country’s challenges in the area of governance and have shaped the agenda’s of both internal and external stakeholders. So, there is a good reason to believe that the findings of the 2020 NIS assessment most likely to have important influence on policies in the coming months and years. It is particularly alarming that, according to the NIS assessment, a majority of institutions had experienced a decline since the last NIS assessment in 2015. TI Georgia has been arguing for years that while petty corruption in Georgia is on relatively low level, high level corruption is main matter of concern. Addressing this issue TI Georgia in 2020 published an open-ended catalogue of the alleged cases of high-level corruption. Unfortunately majority of cases have not been addressed properly if at all by authorities. However, this publication pushes ahead and advocates of more effective anti-corruption policies. Among many activities of TI Georgia in 2020 some gave very tangible results, directly affecting population. For example TI Georgia continued provided free legal services to the population and their lawyers won in 2020 about thirty cases in courts that lead to payment of compensations by the state to those persons who were illegally dismissed or returning land to those whose land was illegally expropriated. TI Georgia continued support in creation and organising what they call Committees of Concerned Citizens (CCCs). TI Georgia through CCCs encourages active citizens especially in regions, in villages and communities to identify local problems and advocate for change through presenting those problems to the city councils in timely and orderly manner and thus achieving budgeting and eventually solving of them. Thus roads were built, water systems rehabilitated, street lights installed, kindergarten construction started, etc. All together more than 100 infrastructural problemd were addressed in Samgrelo, Imereti, Ajara, Kakheti and Samtskhe-Javakheti regions. TI Georgia followed up intensively challenges that raised together with Covid19 pandemic spread. It studied possible corruption cases that where linked to pandemic management when big number of procurements happened through direct procurement. TI Georgia identified suspicions cases and gave recommendations for actions by state authorities. As the year 2020 was a parliamentary election year TI Georgia was especially active in working towards the objective that is formulated as "Promote more pluralistic political system through greater transparency and accountability in political parties and more competitive and fair elections". TI Georgia monitored possible misuse of administrative resources during the elections and studied the Funding of the 2020 Parliamentary Election Campaign. On the election day TI Georgia monitored the parliamentary elections with up to 600 Short Term Observers that was the biggest election monitoring mission in TI Georgia history. TI Georgia assessed in their final report the election and came to conclusion that the 31 October 2020 elections were a step back compared with the 2016 parliamentary elections. The report speaks a lot about TI activities but it is not always clear to what results those activities lead. This is something that Embassy needs to discuss with TI in order to have more result oriented reporting.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
